questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV positive male presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough and significant weight loss. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture with features of atypical pneumonia and CXR showing bilateral reticulonodular infiltrates is suggestive of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an HIV/AIDS-defining opportunistic infection. The clinical manifestations include profound weight loss, fever, dyspnea, and non-productive cough. Chest X-ray shows diffuse infiltrates beginning in the perihilar region (characteristic) and atypical manifestations include nodular lesions, cavitary lesions, etc.

The first cases of Pneumocystis pneumonia in humans were initially recognized in Central Europe after the Second World War in premature and malnourished infants.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of serous discharge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. What is the location of the internal opening?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is diagnostic of Fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8’O clock position which implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline.

According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline (6’O clock position). Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at 6’O clock position.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

questions.text: A 18-year-old female came to OPD with complaints of backache. On examination she had hyperpigmentation of eyes and nose and the following findings are seen. This condition is  characterized by a deficiency of _________.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of ochronosis,which is a clinical manifestation of Alkaptonuria and it is due to the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate.

In ochronosis the excess homogentisic acid is oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-coloured alkapton bodies, which deposits in soft tissues like cartilage which leads to arthritis and pigmentation of the connective tissue.

This results in the classical clinical features of alkaptonuria such as- 

  • Homogentisic aciduria- Black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 
  • Ochronosis- Bluish-black discoloration of tissues mostly involving ear cartilage, ocular tissue, the skin of the eyelids, forehead, cheeks, and hands, nail beds, and even deeper structures such as the larynx and tendons.
  • Arthropathy- Debilitating arthralgia or arthritis that may be seen after the fourth or fifth decade.

Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, and knee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications. In children, blackening of the urine on standing is observed; it is caused by the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid.

Diagnosis: It is by demonstrating massive excretion of homogentisic acid in urine.

Treatment: Nitisinone is used in this condition as it effectively decreses  homogentisic acid production. Arthritis is treated symtomatically.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true concerning a live-donor kidney transplant?

choices.text: The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site for kidney placement
The renal artery is anastomosed end-to-end to the external iliac artery.
The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the internal iliac vein
Right kidney is preferred over the left for transplantation.

questions.solution:
The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site chosen for kidney placement during transplantation.

Live donor 

  • The donor renal artery is anastomosed end-to-end with the internal iliac artery.
  • The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-end with the external iliac vein.

Deceased donor

  • The renal artery is anastomosed, in an end-to-side fashion, to the common or external iliac artery.
  • The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the external iliac vein or the common iliac vein.

The left kidney is preferred for transplantation because the left renal vein is longer.

Note: In the case of a deceased donor, the arterial graft is traced until the aorta which makes it longer, and hence end-to-side anastomosis is possible. Whereas, in the case of a live donor, the arterial graft cannot be extended until the aorta.

questions.text: Migratory necrolytic skin rash is seen in?
questions.solution:
Glucagonoma is a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas.

It can present with migratory necrolytic skin rash.

Other symptoms include glossitis, stomatitis, and angular cheilitis.

Diabetes, severe weight loss and diarrhea can also occur.

The risk of malignancy is 80%.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both the sexes.

Puberty in females involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).

Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips. Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification and cervical mucus production, induce closure of the epiphyses, have a positive effect in maintaining bone formation, and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

questions.text: The image shows plain CT of a patient with head injury. The diagnosis is ____.
questions.solution:
The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with mass effect.

Extradural hematoma (EDH)

  • EDH is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery (pterion is the thinnest part of the skull and overlies middle meningeal artery).
  • The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.
  • Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis. Sometimes, herniation may be associated with a false localising ipsilateral hemiparesis, known as the Kernohan-Woltman notch phenomenon, in which the free edge of the tentorium compresses the contralateral crus cerebri in the midbrain.

questions.text: The perforation shown in the image is _______________
questions.solution:
The given image shows a subtotal perforation as it involves all four quadrants of the tympanic membrane but is covered by remnant pars tensa/annulus all around.

Related Pearl: Types of tympanic membrane perforation

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following is true with respect to this lesion?

choices.text: Vascular lesions characterised by the tortuous constriction of arterioles
Fill from the outer to center on applying and releasing pressure over the lesion
Seen in estrogen-deficient states such as emergency pill use and pregnancy
Mainly seen in chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease

questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi and it is mainly seen in chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease.

Spider naevi (nevus araneus) are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the center outward.

They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use.
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease, and
  • Thyrotoxicosis

questions.text: The given image illustrates a flap used for breast reconstruction. Name the flap.
questions.solution:
The image illustrates a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap.

In the above image, it is clearly seen that only skin and subcutaneous fat are moved. In contrast, the skin, fat, and muscle are moved in a TRAM flap.

Deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap

  • It is a free flap.
  • Only subcutaneous fat and skin is taken.
  • The rectus abdominis muscle is not removed, and hence, there is no abdominal wall weakness.
  • Cosmetically, it is the best flap, and it has the advantage of giving a "tummy tuck" to the patient as well.

 Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap

  • Either based on superior epigastric or inferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM)
  • Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest.
  • The rectus abdominis muscle is excised, and hence, the procedure leads to abdominal wall weakness (hernias can occur).

Latissimus dorsi flap:

  • Based on the thoracodorsal pedicle
  • It is an Axial flap

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought in to the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There is no history of fever, night sweats, and weight loss. MRI  was done and the ​image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cerebral toxoplasmosis is the most likely diagnosis, favored by presentation with seizures in a patient with HIV and the MRI features of a solitary rim-enhancing lesion in the left posterior frontal lobe, moderate surrounding vasogenic edema, and a midline shift to the right.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis:

  • It is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL.
  • It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Diagnosis:

MRI:

  • Usually multiple lesions in multiple locations, however, in some cases a single lesion may be present.
  • These lesion/s are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI.
  • Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring, this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis.
  • Surrounding edema is usually present.

Differential diagnosis:

Other conditions with single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include primary CNS lymphoma (usually solitary, solid and subependymal lesion) and, less commonly, TB or fungal or bacterial abscesses. 

Treatment:

Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Prophylaxis:

  • Primary prophylaxis to prevent the first occurrence of the toxoplasmosis infection,given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given. The same regimen also offers primary protection against P. jirovecii. 
  • Secondary prophyaxis / maintanace therapy,to prevent the recurrence of toxoplasmosis infection if CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL. Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. Secondary prophylaxis is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months. 

Other options:

  • Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen.
  • Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients.
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) caused by JC virus is AIDS defining and is characterized by demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, nonenhancing white matter lesions.

questions.text: The urinary bladder shown in the MCU image below is commonly diagnostic of _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder, in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall. It is typically seen in severe neurogenic bladder.

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.

There are five types of neurogenic bladder based on the site of the lesion.

  1. Sensory neurogenic bladder: posterior columns of the spinal cord or afferent tracts leading from the bladder
  2. Motor paralytic bladder: damage to motor neurons of the bladder
  3. Uninhibited neurogenic bladder: incomplete spinal cord lesions above s2 or cerebral cortex or cerebropontine axis lesions
  4. Reflex neurogenic bladder: complete spinal cord lesions above s2 - may lead to pine cone bladder

Autonomous neurogenic bladder: conus or cauda equina lesions.

Other options:

Option A: Bladder diverticula appear as outpouchings or sacs arising from the bladder wall, which may be visible on an MCU as small, round, or oval outpouchings.

Option B: A cystic pelvic mass would generally be seen as a discrete cystic structure separate from the bladder.

Option D: Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) involves the abnormal backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureters. On an MCU, VUR would show contrast ascending into the ureters .

questions.text: A 70 years old man on anticoagulants due to some heart disease suffered a minor head injury. One month later he has severe headache with slowly developing neurological signs. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic subdural hematoma.

Chronic subdural hematoma is a common cause of acute neurological deterioration in the elderly. Cerebral atrophy in this age group results in stretching of cortical–dural bridging veins, which are then vulnerable to rupture. The resulting hematoma can expand over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately producing symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits.

There is usually a history of recent injury, but especially in the context of antiplatelet or anticoagulant medication even apparently trivial impacts may be responsible.

All other conditions, given as options present with rapid deterioration of neurological signs and symptoms along with the history of high-energy impact injury. Hence, they are ruled out.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortion. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome?
questions.solution:
Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.

The procedure involves the resection of septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the outcomes.

Jones metroplasty, Strassmann metroplasty, Tompkins metroplasty involve approaching the uterus transabdominally which causes uterine scarring and are hence not preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Bishop score?
questions.solution:
The type of maternal pelvis is not a component of the Bishop score.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess the inducibility. It is based on the station, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991) the effacement is replaced by a cervical length in cm.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

NOTE: 6-13 seems to be a general consensus for a favorable score.

  • To be specific, according to NICE guidelines -A score of 8 or more generally indicates that the cervix is ripe. 
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (25th edition) - A score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.
  • A score of 5 or less is an indication for induction by cervical ripening agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are resected in hepatic flexure cancer?

choices.text: A, B, C, D, E, F
A, B, C, D, E, F, G
A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H

questions.solution:
In the given image, A, B, C, D, E, F, G represents the terminal 10 cm of ileum, the right colon, and proximal transverse colon, which are resected in hepatic flexure cancer.

An extended right colectomy is preferred for curative-intent resection of lesions located at the hepatic flexure or proximal transverse colon.

Extended right colectomy:

  • The ileocolic vessels, right colic vessels, and middle colic vessels (at the base) are ligated and divided.
  • Approximately 10 cm of terminal ileum, the right colon, and proximal transverse colon are resected, and a primary anastomosis is created between the distal ileum and distal transverse colon.
  • Such an anastomosis relies on the marginal artery of Drummond.

questions.text: What is the correct order of the normal phases of wound healing?

choices.text: Proliferative phase > Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Remodeling phase
Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Inflammatory phase > Hemostatic phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Remodeling phase > Proliferative phase > Destructive phase > Inflammatory phase

questions.solution:
The correct order of the normal phases of wound healing is as follows: Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase.

Inflammatory phase: begins immediately after wounding and lasts 2-3 days. Bleeding is followed by vasoconstriction and thrombus formation to limit blood loss. Occasionally, the early part of inflammatory phase is called hemostatic phase.

Proliferative phase lasts from 3rd day to 3rd week consisting mainly of fibroblast activity with production of collagen and ground substance, growth of new blood vessels and re-epithelialization of the wound surface.

Remodeling phase is characterized by maturation of collagen- type 1 replacing type 3 until a ratio of 4:1 is achieved. The mature collagen leads to increased tensile strength and represents approximately 80% of the uninjured skin strength.

questions.text: False statement regarding Down’s syndrome is?

choices.text: Most common cardiovascular lesion is endocardial cushion defect
It is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability
Most common cause of intestinal obstruction is intussusception
AML is more common during first 3 years of life

questions.solution:
Most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down’s syndrome is duodenal atresia. 

Clinical features of Down’s syndrome: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere) 

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly 
  • Congenital heart disease 
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum 
  • Protruding tongue 
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth 
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots 
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge 
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic 
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure) 
  • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes 

Note: 

  • Down’s syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability. 
  • Most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign). 
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).  
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life. 
  • Most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML).  
  • Most common hematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM). 
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese female who has recently been diagnosed with NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steato Hepatitis). She is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive and she had never consumed alcohol. Which of the following can be considered for the first line of treatment in this lady?
questions.solution:
Vitamin E can be considered for the first line of treatment in this nondiabetic female with NASH.

Vitamin E was well tolerated and showed modest improvements in aminotransferase levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH. Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.

questions.text: A person fell backwards and landed on the dorsal part of one of his elbows. He complains of severe pain behind the elbow. His X-ray is given below. Which of the following is a treatment method in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of the olecranon. Tension band wiring is one of the management methods in this case. 

The Mayo classification divides olecranon fractures into three groups based on fracture displacement and elbow stability. Each group is further subdivided into comminuted (A) or noncomminuted (B). 

  • Type I (undisplaced)
  • Type II (displaced but stable)
  • Type III (unstable)

Management:

Type I can be managed nonoperatively, while Type II and III generally require surgery. 

  • Simple olecranon fractures without comminution or instability are managed with tension-band wiring, plate fixation, or an intramedullary rod.
  • Comminuted fractures and fractures with elbow instability are managed with plate fixation.
  • In osteoporotic patients when there is significant comminution, excision of the olecranon with triceps advancement is done.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man sustained a road traffic accident and has a large wound on the thigh. After initial wound management, the plastic surgeon decides to cover the wound with the following type of graft (image below).  This graft survives by the process of plasma imbibition till which time period?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts the harvesting of a split skin graft. Split skin graft survives by the process of plasma imbibition till 48hrs following transplantation surgery.

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hrs because of imbibition of plasma from wound bed.
  • After 48 hrs, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to inosculation of blood.
  • Revascularization is the process by which new blood vessels directly invade the graft and restore the pink hue of the skin.

questions.text: Identify the procedure in the image.
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is the Billroth II gastrectomy.

  • Billroth I gastrectomy: The lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.
  • Billroth II gastrectomy: Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retrocolic fashion, to the jejunum.
  • Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy: Billroth II reconstruction with jejunujenunostomy.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in
questions.solution:
The remnants of Wolffian ducts(Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. The duct sometimes forms a cyst, called Gartner’s cyst, in the broad ligament or in the vagina.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to your clinic with complaints of slowly progressive reddish-brown skin lesions, with itching and scaling located predominantly over the non-sun-exposed parts of his body for the past couple of years. On examination, there are bluish and reddish-brown ulcerated plaques and nodules. Histopathology reveals the following finding. Identify the structure marked by the arrow in the image given below
questions.solution:
The arrow mark is pointing towards a collection of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis termed as Pautrier microabscess. This is a very important histopathology feature of Mycoses fungoides which is the most common type of cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma is commonly seen in men more than 40 years of age. Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Other types include Sezary syndrome which occurs when the malignant cells from the skin enter the circulation. It is characterized by erythroderma.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of COPD now complains of swelling in both feet for 6 months, dyspnoea on exertion and dry cough for 1 week. An ECG was done and the lead II showed this pattern. Which of the following options is responsible for this ECG finding?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called "P pulmonale".  The patient is showing features of right heart failure and right atrial overload is responsible for the above ECG finding.

The features of P pulmonale include:

  • Amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II.
  • Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1.

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. On examination, there is tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes, and serology is positive for anti echinococcal antibodies. You order for an abdominal ultrasound.  It shows the following finding. As per the 2001 WHO classification, to which type does this hydatid cyst belong?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound image is of active hydatid cyst with multiple septations and rosette or honeycomb appearance. As per the WHO classification of cystic echinococcosis (CE), it belongs to type 2 (CE2).

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with a USG report suggesting fetus in breech position and on per vaginal examination, toes of the foot can be felt. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests that the fetus is in a footling breech position, which is an indication for a cesarean section.

In footling breech, one or both legs are extended at the hip, so that the foot is the presenting part.

A major complication of breech presentation is cord prolapse. In the cord prolapse, the umbilical cord drops down below the presenting part of the baby and becomes compressed.

Factors favoring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus:

  • Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Primi with breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

Other options:

Option A: Intrernal podalic version is a maneuver used only in the delivery of a second twin. (Option A)

Option C: External cephalic version is a maneuver used before labor in a woman who has reached 36 weeks’ gestation with a breech fetus. (Option C)

Option D: Assisted breech delivery is performed when there are no factors favoring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus. (Option D)

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Footling Knee presentation Complete/flexed
Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Both thighs and legs are partially extended Thighs extended, Knee flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed.
Presenting part: Buttocks and genitalia Foot Knee Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recommendation under The Baby Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI)?

choices.text: Counsel mothers on the risk of using feeding bottles

questions.solution:
4 hourly breastfeeding is not a recommendation under  The Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative.

World Breastfeeding Week is a global campaign celebrated 1-7 August every year. World Breastfeeding Week aims to highlight the huge benefits that breastfeeding can bring to both the health and welfare of babies, as well as for maternal health. The theme for year 2020 is “Support Breastfeeding for a healthier planet,
Covid-19 is an opportunity to strengthen action on breastfeeding”

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new minor Jones criteria in high risk population according to American Heart Association and World Heart Federation 2015 criteria?
questions.solution:
Monoarthralgia is a new minor Jones criterion in moderate-high risk population.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal antigen implicated in Pemphigus Vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Desmoglein 3  is the principal antigen implicated in Pemphigus Vulgaris.

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an immunobullous disease or a chronic blistering disease which occurs due to an autoimmune process, by the production of antibodies (usually IgG) against desmosomal proteins called desmogleins(adhesion proteins).
  • In pemphigus vulgaris, desmoglein 3 is the principal antigen against which autoantibodies are produced.
  • Desmoglein 1 and Desmocollins are also implicated at later stages of disease progression.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college-going student was brought to the casualty following a stab injury. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg and was diagnosed with hemorrhagic shock.  All of the following are minimum standards for monitoring this patient except?
questions.solution:
Central venous pressure does not come under the minimum standard for monitoring of a patient in shock. It is one of the additional modalities to be done in shock patients.

The minimum standard modalities for monitoring patients in shock are

  • ECG
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Blood pressure
  • Urine output

The additional modalities are

  • Central venous pressure
  • Invasive blood pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Base deficit and serum lactate

Best clinical indicator of fluid resuscitation: Urine output, best indicated by urine output of  >0.5 mL/kg/h in adults and >1 mL/kg/h in children.

Best indicator to determine the amount of fluid required in a patient with shock: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)

questions.text: A 51 year old gentleman was being worked up for hepatocellular function. He had no history or signs of hepatic encephalopathy. The Child-Turcotte-Pugh score for the given patient is 7 which is classified as Class B.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked A:
questions.solution:
The structure marked is primary oocyte.

  • Primary oocyte are the germ cells in the medullary region of the ovary which enlarge at the beginning of the growth phase until puberty.

  • During this cell growth period, many oocytes undergo degeneration, both before and after birth. A single layer of flattened follicular cells that were derived originally from the germinal epithelium soon surrounds the primary oocytes. These structures are now called primordial follicles and are seen first in the medulla and later in the cortex.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the OPD with fever, cough with scanty sputum ,multiple joint pains and headache. A chest x-ray was done and had the appearance as below .A mycoplasma infection was suspected and confirmed. Which of the following treatment options would not be recommended in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by mycoplasma and ciprofloxacin is not a recommended treatment.

Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia and the second most common cause of pneumonia. Clinically it has a very non-specific presentation. Only 10% of patients present with pneumonia. URTI (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) is the common pulmonary manifestation. It is mainly characterized by its extrapulmonary manifestations. Extrapulmonary manifestations include Cold agglutinin disease (IgM mediated AIHA), Erythema multiforme or SJS, arthralgia with adenopathy, Guillain Barre syndrome, myocarditis, pericarditis, encephalitis, and bullous myringitis. 

Treatment options for Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection include:

  •  Macrolides (e.g. azithromycin)
  •  Tetracyclines (e.g. doxycycline)
  • Respiratory fluoroquinolones. (e.g. levofloxacin)

Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

However, ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin are not recommended because of their high minimal inhibitory concentrations against Mycoplasma pneumoniae isolates and their poor performance in experimental studies.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays. On chest X-ray patchy consolidation at hilum and fanning to the periphery. On PPLO agar (Dienes method) it shows a biphasic with fried-egg appearance.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with lesions on her face as shown in the image. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The Image shows typical erythematous papules and nodules along with few whiteheads. The face appears to be very oily as well which suggests acne vulgaris. This comes under grade III acne.

Option B: Acne rosacea presents with erythema and papules on facial convexities (central face), a characteristic feature of acne rosacea. It is triggered by exposure to sunlight, spicy food, alcohol, or emotional disturbances. Patients also develop telangiectasia later. They also have a tendency for developing rapid flushing due to temperature change. Rosacea is more common in women of age 30 to 50 years.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought to the hospital with sudden onset abdominal pain and vomiting.  During clinical examination, tenderness was present near the right iliac fossa, and McBurney's sign positive. Which of the following investigation is preferred in this child for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, the likely diagnosis is acute appendicitis and the investigation preferred in this child for diagnosis is USG.

A CT scan is the most effective and accurate imaging modality for appendicitis, but in pediatric and pregnant patients, USG is preferred to avoid the risk of radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to the ER with complaints of severe pain behind his breast bone associated with sweating and giddiness. He has a blood pressure of 86/54 mm Hg. The electrocardiogram recorded on him is given below. Which of the following would be efficient management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG showing ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF are suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Since the patient has hypotension, the best management strategy is brisk administration of fluids to combat the cardiogenic shock that would set in, if untreated.

Sublingual nitroglycerine, intravenous morphine, and intravenous furosemide can reduce the preload and hence should be avoided in an MI complicated by hypotension.

In the setting of inferior wall infarction, signs of cardiogenic shock should prompt the suspicion for a right ventricular infarction. And the same can be evidenced by ST elevation in the right precordial leads (V4R, V5R, V6R).

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: 57 year old comes to the ER after sustaining a fall to the head from a roof of 6 ft. He complaints of headache and he appears to be confused. Which of the following is the classic CT appearance of an acute subdural hematoma?
questions.solution:
A crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines on axial CT is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Typically unilateral (85%) 
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

Lentiform (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion that does not cross suture lines on axial CT: Epidural hemorrhage

Image 1: CT image of acute subdural hemorrhage.

Image 2: CT image of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage.

questions.text: Expansion of the contrast-filled space in myelography is seen in _________.
questions.solution:
The contrast in myelography is injected into the CSF space, and if the tumor is present in the intradural extramedullary space, it leads to the widening of the CSF space on that side. Examples of such lesions include neurofibroma/meningioma. These lesions will also show a meniscus-like appearance on myelography with the contrast column.

 

 

Image (below): The sagittal T1-weighted post-contrast image reveals an extramedullary dural-based mass lesion. The mass enhances homogeneously. 

 

 

Image: The sagittal T2-weighted image demonstrates the hyperintense mass intramedullary tumor. Intramedullary lesions will lead to “trouser leg” appearance on myelography due to cord expansion.

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:
questions.solution:
Bilateral hydrosalpinx is observed in the given image of hysterosalpingogram.

Hydrosalpinx is the distension of the fallopian tubes following the collection of fluid in the lumen. It is often bilateral and occurs following acute salpingitis. The tubes are retort shaped due to dilatation of the ampulla and filled with a clear fluid. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. They may be as large as 15 cms. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: ETDRS study was related to?
questions.solution:
Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a randomized clinical trial that studied the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema. 

The results of the study demonstrated the beneficial effects of focal photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema. The study resulted in the recommendation that all eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred treatment method in severe twin to twin transfusion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS - Quintero stages 2 to 4.

Among the other options, septostomy is seldom done. Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid. Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.

Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and reduced likelihood of recurrence.

Quintero staging:  

  • Stage I—Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor bladder
  • Stage II—Stage I +Urine not visible in donor bladder
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV—frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—demise of either fetus.

questions.text: You are on duty in the Gastroenterology department for super specialty rotations as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the endoscopic images given below?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A is of ulcerative colitis and image B is of Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between which indicates ulcerative colitis. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

A Mallory-Weiss tear is a tear of the tissue of your lower esophagus most often caused by violent coughing or vomiting.

questions.text: A 24 year old primi with a history of 3 months of amenorrhoea undergoes USG.  The USG done is suggestive of
questions.solution:
The above USG is suggestive of Hydatidiform mole.

The USG shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance which is seen in hydatidiform mole.

It is of 2 types

  • Complete mole - grossly appear as a mass of clear vesicles.
  • Partial mole - has less hydatidiform changes and contains some fetal tissue.


Classical clinical features of a complete mole are-

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early onset preeclampsia
  • Uterus appears large for date
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries of more than 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/ml
  • USG - snowstorm appearance.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent epigastric pain with burning sensation for the past 2 years. The pain usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food. He also says that he sometimes wakes up at night because of severe pain. The most probable cause for his symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Epigastric pain with burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer.

The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease:

Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep.

Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.

Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm.

Penetrating ulcer- It is a type of perforation where the ulcer tunnels into an adjacent organ like the pancreas/liver. In this case, the pain is no longer relieved by food or antacids and might radiate to the back.

Many patients with peptic ulcers, especially elderly patients, may not have these symptoms and may directly present with a complication like bleeding or perforation.

questions.text: In Rh -ve sensitised mother, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring of the fetus in modern obstetrics?
questions.solution:
MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mother. PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity. 

If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is lesser than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced amniocentesis as the preferred test for anemia detection.

choices.text: It involves both the myenteric plexus and Meissner’s plexus
It is seen in infants only.
It can also involve the small intestine.

questions.solution:
The image depicts barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid descending colon characteristic of Hirschsprung's disease.

Hirschsprung’s disease can also occur in older children.

 Hirschsprung’s disease:

  • Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus.
  • Incidence: 1 in 5000 live births.
  • Boys are four times more frequently affected than girls.
  • Sites affected: Rectosigmoid (80%) > Splenic or transverse colon (17%) > Entire colon with variable extension to small bowel (8%).
  • The abnormal/aganglionic bowel is the constricted distal segment, whereas the normal bowel is the proximal dilated portion.

questions.text: Based on histopathological examination of benign breast tissue, which of the following has increased relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Papilloma with a fibrovascular core on histopathological examination of benign breast tissue has a moderately increased risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma.

All other histopathological patterns have no increased relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma according to American College of Pathologists Consensus Statement.

Relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on pathological examination of benign breast tissue:

No increased risk :

Adenosis, sclerosing or florid

Apocrine metaplasia

Cysts, macro and/or micro

Duct ectasia

Fibroadenoma

Fibrosis

Hyperplasia

Mastitis (inflammation)

Periductal mastitis

Squamous metaplasia

Slightly increased risk (1.5–2 times):

Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid or papillary

Papilloma with a fibrovascular core

Moderately increased risk (5 times):

Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular)

questions.text: A patient in the emergency ward rolls around on the bed in a futile attempt to find a position free from pain. This attitude of the patient is most likely to be because of
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is most likely to be due to renal colic. A patient of renal colic would have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain and tries to find a pain free position.

On the contrary, a patient with peritonitis lies supine without movement and also has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain in peritonitis.

A patient of acute pancreatitis usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest position because of abdominal pain. A patient of meningitis would have neck stiffness.

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness since 1 hour. Her CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient and the next step should be intravenous thrombolysis as she is in the window period.

Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase: 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in window period (within 3/4.5 hours of symptom onset).

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the clinic after he experienced palpitations. He has a history of IHD.  Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the condition identified on the given ECG:
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with a mid-tibial swelling, with complaints of severe pain at night which reduces after taking aspirin. What is the best investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
A child in 2nd decade which severe night pain and relieved by aspirin (NSAIDs) best explains the condition of osteoid osteoma. 

The nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma. 

Osteoid osteoma:

  • It is a benign neoplasm most often seen in young men. 
  • The typical patient with an osteoid osteoma has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other nonsteroidal antiinﬂammatory medications. 
  • The nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma. 
  • It is the most common true benign tumor of the bone. 

Treatment: 

  • NSAIDs 
  • Radiofrequency ablation 
  • Surgical Resection by curettage and en bloc resection (has lower recurrence rate) 
  • MR-guided focused USG (Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) ablation is a new technique in which ultrasound waves are focused on the osteoid osteoma. When high-intensity waves are focused on a single point, considerable heat is generated.) 

MRI is used for both localization of the tumor and temperature monitoring. Note: In Osteoblastoma-Pain similar in character as osteoid osteoma(worse at night and relieved by NSAIDs).

questions.text: A 7 year old child presents to the clinic with the following skin lesion. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
This "classic" bull's-eye rash is also called erythema migrans. This lesion is usually seen in individuals with Lyme’s disease.
In children with Lyme disease amoxicillin is the drug of choice.

Doxycycline is generally the drug of choice in Lyme’s disease except in pregnant, lactating women and children under 8 where amoxicillin is used.
Doxycycline is preferred because it has excellent CNS penetration and it can be used to treat anaplasmosis which can coexist with the Lyme’s disease.

Ceftriaxone is reserved for patients with late neurological findings.
Although Azithromycin can be used for treatment treating with amoxicillin gave superior results and shorter treatment time.

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur?
questions.solution:
Fertilization usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

After ovulation, the ovum is propelled towards the uterine cavity by the peristaltic action of the fallopian tubes and can only be fertilized within 24 hours. If coitus takes place during this period, the spermatozoa swimming up into the tubes meet the ovum in the ampulla.

The ampulla is also the most common site of ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the treatment of PCOD except?
questions.solution:
Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of PCOD (Polycystic ovarian disease). It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator.

Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that is used in PCOD patients who presents with infertility. But nowadays Letrozole (anti-estrogen drug) is more effective in ovulatory infertility in obese women. But this is an off label use of Letrozole. Clomiphene with dexamethasone improves the fertility rate.

Surgical management includes Laparoscopic ovarian drilling. It is recommended as second-line therapy.

Indications of surgery:

  • Failed medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone >2 ng/mL, free T >2.2 pg/mL (Normal level 0.2–0.8 ng/mL)
    • Normal androstenedione level is 1.3–1.5 ng/mL
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: Vidian neurectomy is done in a case of:
questions.solution:
Vidian neurectomy i.e. sectioning of parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to nose is done in case of vasomotor rhinitis.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Submucous resection operation and septoplasty are done for DNS.

Option B: Allergic rhinitis is only managed medically.

Option C: Atrophic rhinitis is managed both medically and surgically. The surgical options are,

Young’s operation - Both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. They are opened after 6 months or later. In these cases, mucosa may revert to normal and crusting reduced.

Modified Young’s operation- aims at partially closing the nostrils. Result is same as Young’s operation.

  • Interstitial keratitis

Other option:

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with the features shown in the image below. Brain MRI revealed pedunculated hypothalamic hamartoma. All of the following statements regarding this condition are true except:

choices.text: Hypothalamic hamartomas are nonneoplastic developmental lesions
Premature activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis
GnRH antagonist is used in the treatment of this condition
Induce early bone maturation and reduce eventual adult height

questions.solution:
A 4-year-old girl exhibiting breast development, as shown in the image, presented with precocious puberty. GnRH agonists are used in the treatment of this condition 

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years.

GnRH agonists are the treatment of choice for precocious puberty.

  • Hypothalamic hamartomas are nonneoplastic developmental lesions that are usually histologically normal in appearance, but ectopic in position (Option A)
  • These lesions are believed to cause precocious puberty through the endogenous pulsatile release of GnRH, either independently or in concert with the GnRH-secreting neurons of the hypothalamus.
  • Premature activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis (Option B) manifests as gonadotropin-dependent precocious puberty.
  • Early sexual development in children warrants evaluation because it may:
    • Induce early bone maturation and reduce eventual adult height, (Option D)
    • Indicate the presence of a tumor or other serious problem
  • One possible treatment is with anastrozole. Histrelin acetate (Supprelin LA), triptorelin or leuprolide, any GnRH agonists, may be used.

Understanding the rationale behind the use of GnRH agonist in the treatment of precocious puberty:

The normal:

  • GnRH neurons are normally inhibited by the CNS until puberty.
  • At the time of puberty (7-8 years for girls, and 9 years for boys), the GnRH neurons escape the inhibition and starts releasing the GnRH in a pulsatile manner.

Effect of pulsatile vs non-pulsatile secretion

  • Pulsatile secretion of GnRH causes stimulation of FSH and LH production.
  • On the other hand, if there is continuous, non-pulsatile release of GnRH, it has the opposite effect, which causes inhibition of FSH and LH, and may cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Uses of GnRH agonist :

  • Continuous administration of GnRH is indicated in the treatment of central precocious puberty. The GnRH agonists are continued until 11 years of age in females and 12 years of age in males. 
  • GnRH agonists are also used in the management of advanced breast and ovarian carcinomas and to induce gonadal suppression in men with prostate cancer.

questions.text: The  ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) and the next best step of management in this patient is synchronized cardioversion.

The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes without visible p waves and pseudo R' waves in aVR lead which is indicative of Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

In this case, carotid massage and IV adenosine have failed to control PSVT and the patient continues to have hemodynamic instability (B.P. - 60/30 mmHg). In this condition, synchronized direct current cardioversion (and not just DC shock) should be initiated with the starting dose of 50-100J. (Option D)

In the absence of hemodynamic instability repeat dose of Inj Adenosine (maximum of 12mg) could be attempted. (Option A)

IV Amiodarone is rarely used in the acute management of PSVT. Instead, it is used as an alternative to calcium channel blockers in chronic suppressive therapy. (Option B)

questions.text: The incision used in endomeatal approach to the ear is?
questions.solution:
Rosen’s incision is used in endomeatal approach to the middle ear.

Endomeatal approach: It is used to raise tympanomeatal flap is order to expose the middle ear. Rosen’s incision is most commonly used in the endomeatal approach for stapedectomy. It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy to find the cause of conductive hearing loss.

Other options:

Lempert I and II incision: Used in Endaural approach

Wilde’s incision: Postaural approach

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family says she has a history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor arrived at a provisional diagnosis based on the clinical features. Which of the following would be the best investigation to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. Sestamibi scan is the best investigation for parathyroid abnormalities. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma.

Sestamibi is a monovalent, lipophilic cation that passively diffuses across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria.

There are mainly two techniques used to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue:

  • Subtraction imaging - This method uses a dual radionu­clide approach with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or either 99mTc pertechnetate.
  • Dual-phase imaging - This method uses sesta­mibi alone with early and delayed imaging.

Sestamibi single-photon emission CT has become the most commonly used preoperative imaging study in parathyroid disease because of its improved spatial resolution.

Sestamibi combined with computed tomography (CT) offers the advantage of detecting smaller parathyroid lesions that would otherwise be undetectable with sestamibi alone.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Abdominal groans
  • Psychic moans
  • Renal stones
  • Bone pain is also seen in hyperparathyroidism (bone resorption)

questions.text: The following anatomical classification of pelvis was given by ______and is based on _________
questions.solution:
This classification is given by Caldwell and Moloy.
This classification is based on shape of the pelvis.
The greatest transverse diameter of the inlet and its division into anterior and posterior segments are used to classify pelvis as

  • Gynaecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

questions.text: All are true regarding Caroli’s disease except?
questions.solution:
The presentation of Caroli’s disease may be with abdominal pain or sepsis and not ascites.

Caroli’s disease:

  1. Caroli’s disease is congenital dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary tree.
  2. There is biliary stasis and sludge formation leading to obstruction of bile flow.
    Patients present with episodes of recurrent bacterial cholangitis: abdominal pain, fevers, chills, and jaundices
  3. At an older age, after the development of hepatic fibrosis, and patients present with signs of portal hypertension such as ascites and variceal bleeding.
  4. Patients with Caroli disease are at an increased risk for the development of cholangiocarcinoma.
  5. This disease is often complicated by the presence of intrahepatic stone formation.
  6. Biliary stasis with stone formation can lead to biliary sepsis.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools, but no history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. Which of the following is not included in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has some degree of dehydration, since the child is restless and irritable, drinks water readily, has sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (<2 seconds). So IV fluids are not used in the management of this condition.

Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding according to WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) Protocol, Plan B.

WHO IMNCI PLANS:

Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Identify the following surgical position:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Kraske Position which is also known as Jack-knife position.

The patient's abdomen lies flat upon the bed which is scissored so the hip is lifted and the legs and head are low.

Pilonidal Sinus /Jeep Disease is operated upon in the Jack-knife position.

The sacrococcygeal region is best exposed in the prone jack-knife position with the buttocks taped apart. A paramedian longitudinal incision is made over the abscess cavity that is large enough to allow for adequate drainage and removal of all debris and hair.

Other options:

Fowler and Semi-fowler position:

Fowler's position is a standard patient position in which the patient is seated in a semi-sitting position (45-60 degrees) and may have knees either bent or straight. 

Semi-Fowler, 30 to 45 degrees; and low Fowler, where the head is slightly elevated.

Sims position:

It is used for rectal examination, treatments, and enemas. It is performed by having a patient lie on their left side, left hip and lower extremity straight, and right hip and knee bent. It is also called lateral recumbent position.

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except?

choices.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal  nerves

questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except for the obturator muscle.

Episiotomy: Surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor is called episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J shaped episiotomy.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

  • Begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline, which yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.
  • Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over the median episiotomy.
  • Increased blood loss.
  • Causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are suggestive of small-vessel vasculitis. Investigating for ANCA should be the next step to lead to the diagnosis.

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3

 Myeloperoxidase

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

Anti-LKM 3
