questions.text: All of the following are causes of a ​ring-enhancing lesion in imaging except ______.
questions.solution:
CNS lymphomas are usually homogenously enhancing solid lesions.

In India, neurocysticercosis and tuberculomas are the commonest causes of a ring-enhancing lesion on brain imaging.

  • Ring-enhancing brain lesions include the following:
    • Neurocysticercosis
    • Tuberculoma
    • Cerebral abscess
    • Metastasis
    • Toxoplasmosis
    • Subacute infarct /hemorrhage/contusion
    • Demyelination (incomplete ring)
    • Tumefactive demyelinating lesion (incomplete ring)
    • Radiation necrosis
    • Postoperative change

Note: Primary CNS lymphoma is usually a homogeneously enhancing solid lesion. However, in the setting of HIV-infected/immunocompromised states, lymphomas may show ring-like enhancement.

Image: Ring-enhancing lesions

  • A = Metastasis
  • B = Abscess
  • C = Radiation necrosis
  • D = Glioblastoma
  • E = Demyelination
  • F = Contusion

questions.text: In the figure given below, the marking A indicates?
questions.solution:
The area marked 'A' represents Caput succedaneum.

Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the area presenting during vertex delivery. It may extend across the midline and across suture lines.

 Difference between Caput Succedaneum and Cephalhematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of head Periosteum of skull bone and bone
Extent of movement Both hemisphere, crosses the suture line Individual bones, doesnot crosses the suture lines
Period of absorption 3-4 days  Few weeks to months

 

Other options:

B-Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp. Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat hyperbilirubinemia.

C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures.

D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

Related Pearl: Caput and Cephalohematoma

questions.text: The skull X Ray shown is diagnostic of _________
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows cotton wool skull which is diagnostic of paget’s disease.

Radiographic features: The early phase features osteolytic (lucent) region which is later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement. Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. The lesions seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

Cotton wool appearance:

Tam O Shanter hat sign, with the hat it looks like:

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 42-year-old male patient you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
COPD does not cause clubbing.

This image demonstrates clubbing. It is characterised by increased distal fingertip mass and increased longitudinal and transverse nail plate curvature. The angle between the nail plate and the proximal nail fold (Lovibond angle) when viewed from the side, is >180° in clubbed nails and 160° in normal nails.

COPD is not a cause of clubbing. But in case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Interstitial Lung Disease, Sarcoidosis, Bronchiectasis are all causes of clubbing.

questions.text: Patient presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of difficulty switching from one movement to another. He also reports having uncontrolled hand movements when trying to perform rapid alternating movements, particularly when asked to tap his fingers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has difficulty switching from one movement to another which is suggestive of Dysdiadochokinesia. It is the inability to perform rapid alternate movements.

It is a clinical manifestation of cerebellar dysfunction and is most evident when strength and sensation are intact. Focal lesions in the nervous system may produce highly asymmetric dysdiadochokinesia. 

The following movement is the method to check for dysdiadochokinesis. The patient is showing normal movement, with no dysdiadochokinesis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Resting tremor is an involuntary, rhythmic muscle movement that occurs when the affected body part is at rest and diminishes with voluntary movement. It is commonly associated with Parkinson's disease and basal ganglia dysfunction.

Option B: Intentional tremor is a slow, rhythmic tremor that occurs during purposeful movement and worsens as the target approaches. It is commonly seen in cerebellar disorders, such as multiple sclerosis or stroke.

Option D: Bradykinesia is the slowness of voluntary movements, often accompanied by reduced amplitude and difficulty initiating actions. It is a hallmark symptom of Parkinson’s disease and other basal ganglia disorders.

Related Pearl: Functions of cerebellum

Vestibulo cerebellum
  • It is concerned with maintainence of balance and equilibirium.
  • It is responsible for regulating the stability of head and body in space.
  • It adjusts the tone of the trunk muscle.
  • Controls the oculur movements and other postural reflexes. 
Spino cerebellum
  • Maintains the posture and helps in execution of gross movements.
  • It controls the interplay between the agonist and antagonist group of muscles.
  • It is essential for the control of rapid muscular activities like running and talking.
Cerebro cerebellum (Neocerebellum)
  • Controls fine, highly precise and coordinated movements.
  • It is involved in programming of voluntary and skilled movements
  • It plays a major role in the timing of the motor activities and rapid progression from one movement to the next.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ECG patient represents normal ECG without a pulse - i.e. the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). 1mg epinephrine is the next best step in the management of this patient.

  • The immediate treatment for this is giving chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest until more definitive therapy to the cause can be instituted.
  • The pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms all without a pulse. It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated.

Reversible causes of cardiac arrest:

5 H’s:

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
  • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
  • Hypothermia

5 T’s:

  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Tamponade (cardiac)
  • Toxins
  • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
  • Thrombosis (coronary)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a sore throat and a sandpaper rash as shown in the picture for the past 2 days. Tongue examination shows swollen papillae. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and rash of the child are suggestive of Scarlet fever.

Scarlet fever is a blanching, papular rash, commonly described as a sandpaper rash. It is usually associated with Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis in school-age and adolescent children.

The rash appears within 24–48 hrs of the onset of symptoms (upper respiratory infections). The trunk, underarms, and groin are affected first, and then it spreads to the extremities. Usually, the palms and soles are spared. The circumoral cheeks are erythematous, with pallor around the mouth.

The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: Which is not true regarding the given image?

choices.text: Circular ring in the proximal esophagus

questions.solution:
The given image shows Schatzki’s ring which is a circular ring seen in the distal esophagus.

  • It is usually present at the squamocolumnar junction.
  • The cause is obscure but it is strongly associated with reflux disease.
  • It may be associated with dysphagia and respond to dilatation along with medical anti-reflux therapy.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old infertile male underwent semen analysis. 
Results show: sperm concentration: 10 million/ml; pH: 7.5; volume: 2 mL. The most likely diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
This male, with a sperm concentration of 10 million/mL, has findings suggestive of oligospermia.

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL. Concentrations of 16 million/mL is Normospermia (Option A)

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of sperm analysis.

Other options :

The total sperm motility is less than 40% and the progressive sperm motility is less than 32% in asthenospermia (Option D)

Azoospermia: Absence of sperm in semen (Option C)

Semen analysis  Normal reference value with reference to lower limit 
Volumae 1.5 mL 
pH 7.2–7.8
Viscosity <3 (Scale 0–4)
Sperm concentration 15 million/mL
Total sperm count >39 million/ejaculate
Motility >Progressive motility = 32%
Morphology >4% Normal form
Viability 58% or more living 
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/mL
Round cells  <5 million/mL
Sperm agglutination <10% spermatozoa with adherent particles

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

  • Volume: 1.5 mL
  • PH: 7.2–7.8
  • Viscosity : <3 (scale 0–4)
  • Sperm concentration ≥15 million/mL 
  • Total sperm count: ≥39 million/per ejaculate 
  • Motility: 40% or more with 32% progressive motility
  • Forward progression: >2 (Scale of 0-4)
  • Normal forms: 4% (strict criteria) 
  • Vitality: 58% or more 
  • White blood cells: < 1 million/mL
  • Round cells: 5 million/mL
  • Sperm agglutination: <2 (Scale 0-3)

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty with circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs. An emergency escharotomy is planned by the attending surgeon. Which of the following incision would be made by the surgeon?

choices.text: Depends upon the limb in involved

questions.solution:
Circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs require emergency escharotomy.

The tourniquet effect of this injury is easily treated by incising the whole length of full-thickness burns. This should be done in the mid-axial line, avoiding major nerves.

Key features of escharotomy placement in limbs:

Upper limb: Mid-axial, anterior to the elbow medially to avoid the ulnar nerve

Hand: Midline in the digits. Release muscle compartments if tight. Best done in theatre and with an experienced surgeon

Lower limb: Mid-axial. Posterior to the ankle medially to avoid the saphenous vein.

questions.text: A 4-year-old is brought to the OPD with history of developmental delay. Which of the following is the highest milestone a child of this age is expected to have, ideally?
questions.solution:
A 4 year old hops on one foot.

questions.text: Identify the incision made in LSCS shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows Pfannenstiel incision, which is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus.

Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Other options:

Maylard incision is made parallel to the Pfannenstiel incision at a level 3-8 cm above the superior border of pubic symphysis. Here, in addition to the rectus sheath, the rectus muscles are also transected horizontally.

Lanz incision and Gridiron incision are made in appendicectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 38 weeks of gestation came to the labor room with complaints of decreased fetal movements.  A non-stress test was done and variable decelerations are noted.  It indicates ______
questions.solution:
Variable deceleration indicates Umbilical cord compression.

Deceleration: Decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s.

The non-stress test is a screening test used in the assessment of fetal well-being. It measures fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during pregnancy.

On conducting a NST:

  • Reactive NST: When 2 or more accelerations of more than 15 beats per minute above the baseline and longer than 15 seconds in duration are present in a 20 minute observation then reassure patient and send back home.
  • Non-reactive NST: When there is an absence of any fetal reactivity Biophysical profile(BPP) has to be assessed.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression-

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on Cardiotocography

Fetal heart rate pattern Causes  
Early deceleration

Head compression
Late deceleration

Fetal hypoxia, Placental insufficiency
Variable deceleration Umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to the emergency ward. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the rectal temperature would be the preferred site to measure the core body temperature.

During the extremes of low or high temperatures like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperature.

The infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum (representative of the core body temperature). However, more often it ends up measuring the temperature of the ear canal. This is because of inadequate insertion into the ear canal due to poor manufacturing design or the presence of cerumen. Hence, it is not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following has a score of 2 in Alvarado scoring system?
questions.solution:
In the Alvarado scoring system, tenderness in right iliac fossa and leukocytosis ≥10⨯109 cells/L have two points.

Related Pearl: Alvarado Scoring System

Findings

Points

Migratory right iliac fossa pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea / vomiting

1

Tenderness in right iiliac fossa

2

Rebound tenderness right iliac fossa

1

Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C

1

Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L

2

Shift to the left of neutrophils

1

 

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: A patient is a known case of cervical cancer.  Which of the following factors is not an indication for a hysterectomy to be the treatment of choice in this patient?

choices.text: The uterus is associated with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed

questions.solution:
Conization is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is suspected and Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is confirmed

Conization includes removal oof a cone shaped tissue of cervix of the entire outer margin and endocervical lining short of internal os. This can be used for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. A smaller cone is desirable in young women to avoid abortion or preterm labour.

Hysterectomy (total) is complete removal of the body of the uterus with the cervix.

  • Indications of conization:
    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • The transformation zone is not completely visualized
    • When there is discrepancy of findings between cytology, colposcopy and biopsy
    • Microinvasion is suspected
  • Indications of hysterectomy:
    • Older and parous women
    • Uterus is suspected with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed
    • Microinvasion exists
    • Recurrence or persistent lesion
    • In – situ adenocarcinoma cervix

questions.text: Glaukomflecken is caused by
questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken is seen following ischemia.

They are gray-white epithelia and anterior cortical opacities that occur following an episode of markedly elevated intraocular pressure, like acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Glaukomflecken is anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity.

Vogt’s triad: evidence of previous angle-closure attack.

  • Glaukomflecken
  • Patches of iris atrophy
  • Pigment dispersion on the corneal endothelium

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman of 13 weeks gestation age informs about accidental exposure to radiation during chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical case, the patient should be advised to continue the pregnancy.

The dose to the fetus during the declared term of pregnancy should be less than 1 mSv. This is equivalent to about 2 mSv to the surface of the abdomen of the mother. 

In chest X-ray PA view, the absorbed dose of radiation by the fetus is less than 1 mSv. Hence, pregnancy can be continued.

For fetal doses less than 100mGy, there is no medical justification for terminating a pregnancy because of radiation exposure. According to CDC, radiation dose between 50 mGy to 100 mGy is regarded inconclusive in terms of impact on the fetus.

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below:

choices.text: For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.solution:
The given instrument is fallope ring applicator. It is used in tubal ligation. 

Falope ring sterilization is accomplished by applying silicone rubber bands to the Fallopian tubes. The major advantage is elimination of thermocoagulation. The occlusion is complete in a short segment and offers theoretical possibilities of tubal reconstruction.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: The image of the hands of a patient is given below.  This sign is seen in
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly).

Other options:

  • Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady presents with uterine prolapse. What is the best management for her keeping in mind that she wishes to conceive in the future?
questions.solution:
For women of the age of 29 years who wish to continue their menstrual and childbearing function, sling operation/ cervicopexy is the ideal management.

Protrusion of the vaginal walls at the vaginal orifice and in some cases, the cervix of the uterus down to the level of the vulva while straining is called uterine/genital prolapse.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is posted for inguinal hernia surgery. In order to perform a fast-track surgical procedure, the anesthetic technique of choice is
questions.solution:
Infiltration anesthesia is ideal to perform inguinal hernia repair as a fast-track procedure.

It has a lesser incidence of complications than regional or general anesthesia. Other anesthetic techniques for hernia repair include intercostal block and ilioinguinal nerve block.

Ambulatory/Outpatient anesthesia employs the use of fast - Track surgical techniques to provide adequate surgical anesthesia and minimize postoperative complications in order to reduce the duration of hospital stay.

Disadvantage of infiltration anesthesia - Short duration of anesthesia even when long-acting local anesthetics like bupivacaine are used. Extended-duration local anesthesia can be produced by encapsulating bupivacaine into a biodegradable carrier.

Regional anesthesia is contraindicated in patients with bleeding disorders, those on anticoagulants and with local infections.

Spinal anesthesia has the disadvantage over epidural anesthesia of delayed recovery due to profound motor blockade. Spinal opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil are added to prolong postoperative analgesia and minimize motor block without delaying recovery. But the adverse effects of spinal opioids like nausea, pruritus and postoperative urinary retention are additive.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation?
questions.solution:
Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation.

The above image shows compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus, this compression sometimes leads to supine vena cava syndrome. During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the aorta is resistant to compression, owing to its structure. The vena caval compression normally, however, results in opening up collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygous veins. In some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed.

This results in hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents to the ER with symptoms suggestive of myxedema coma. Which of the following conditions is least likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is least likely in this patient. Clinical manifestations of myxedema coma include decreased consciousness, seizures and hypothermia. The temperature may be as low as 23 oC.

Hypoventilation leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia plays a major role in myxedema pathogenesis. Hypoglycemia and dilutional hyponatremia are also attributed to the development of symptoms.

Myxedema coma is a serious condition with a mortality rate of 20-40%. Interestingly, the clinical outcomes are independent of the detected T4 and TSH levels.

questions.text: An elderly female presents  with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with a stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. She has been treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for 3 months. But the disease is  still progressing. What is your recommendation for further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
The history and image are typical of rheumatoid arthritis. Combination therapy of methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (oral triple therapy) is indicated in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis when the disease is not responding to methotrexate alone.

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are the mainstay of treatment.

Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

Glucocorticoids: Mainly given in active disease. May be administered in low to moderate doses to achieve rapid disease control before the onset of fully effective DMARD therapy, which often takes several weeks or even months. Second, a 1- to 2-week burst of glucocorticoids may be prescribed for the management of acute disease flares.

Biologicals: They are protein therapeutics designed mostly to target cytokines and cell-surface molecules.

They are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. They include:

Anti-TNF alpha agents: Infliximab, etanecerpt, adalimumab, golimumab, certolizumab. Side effects include increased risk of infections, reactivation of latent TB, drug-induced SLE, malignancy, and hepatitis B flares.

Anakinra: IL-1 antagonist

Toclizumab: IL-6 antagonist

Abatacept: Inhibits co-stimulation of T cells

Rituximab-Anti CD-20

Tofacitinib-JAK 3 inhibitor

questions.text: A 42-year-old diabetic man presents with the following image to OPD. Which of the following is not true about the condition shown?

choices.text: Little finger is the most commonly involved
It is 10 times more commonly seen in males as compared to females
Surgery is indicated if flexion deformity is more than 30 degrees at MCPJ and 15 degrees at PIPJ
It is associated with Ledderhose disease and Peyronnie’s disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image points towards diagnosis of Dupuytren’s contracture.

Ring finger is the most commonly involved finger.

Dupuytren's contracture is a proliferating fibroplasia of the subcutaneous palmar tissue, forming nodules of cords along its ulnar border. It results in finger contractures, thinning of subcutaneous fat, pitting of skin and knuckle pads. The trauma of chronic repetitive nature, heredity, occupational causes such as vibrations of machines, and alcoholism are frequent causes.

Male: Female=10:1

Risk factors-: DM, alcohol, epilepsy, smoking, liver disease

Associations-Ledderhose disease -Lesions in plantar fascia                      

Peyronnie’s disease -Plastic induration of penis

Order of involvement-Ring finger>little finger>middle finger>index finger>thumb

Treatment of Dupuytren Disease-Observation is the first line of management.

Nonoperative:

  • External beam radiation
  • Steroid injection
  • Collagenase

Operative: Surgery is indicated if flexion deformity is more than 30 degrees at MCPJ and 15 degrees at PIPJ.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought to the emergency with symptoms of cyanosis, rapid breathing, and failure to thrive. The chest X-ray of the child is given below. Probable diagnosis is ____________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a snowman or figure of 8 appearance. The probable diagnosis in the above case is Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection.

TAPVC: Pulmonary veins instead of draining into left atrium drain into right atrium directly or indirectly. Following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior vena cava or the left innominate vein
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 17-year-old male with a history of chronic respiratory condition, you notice the chest appears as shown in the image below. This is called as
questions.solution:
The image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and adjacent costal cartilages as would be expected in a typical case of Pectus carinatum(Pigeon Chest). This is seen in cases of Marfan’s syndrome, childhood asthma and rickets.

Other options:

Pectus excavatum-The chest is classically deformed (deeply depressed sternum) or pigeon-breast deformity.

Harrison’s Sulcus-refers to a groove at the lower end of the rib cage seen in young children/infants with abnormally weak bones (e.g.rickets) or chronic respiratory disease (e.g. severe asthma).

Rachitic rosary-nodules at the costochondral junctions in rickets.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the casualty with symptoms of sweating, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and yawning. On examination, mydriasis is present with elevated BP. On further questioning, the patient tells that he has not taken his usual dose of the drug for 3 days. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with the classic symptoms of heroin withdrawal.

Heroin withdrawal:

  • Characteristic symptoms: myalgia, arthralgia, abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and sweating.
  • Signs on physical examination: restlessness, elevated heart rate and blood pressure, pupillary dilatation (mydriasis), piloerection, and yawning.

Treatment for opioid dependence

Detoxification:

  • Long-acting opioid agonist: a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent the withdrawal symptoms.
  • Partial agonist: buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine: alpha-2 agonist acts as sympatholytic and reduces the withdrawal symptoms.

Maintenance:

  • Methadone, buprenorphine, LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol): opioid agonists which reduce craving.
  • Naltrexone: An opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, discourages per­sons with opioid dependence from substance seeking behavior.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for carotid endarterectomy in patients with carotid stenosis except:
questions.solution:
Persistent hypertension is not an indication for carotid endarterectomy in patients with carotid stenosis.

The current guidelines for carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients is as follows:

70% or greater carotid stenosis and

  • Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness
  • Contralateral facial paralysis or paresthesia
  • Arm/leg paralysis or paresthesia
  • Hemianopia
  • Dysphasia (if dominant hemisphere)
  • Sensory or visual inattention/neglect

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with a history of vaginal discharge without itching. On examination, the discharge was thin, yellow, nonviscous and adherent to the vaginal wall. She is not sexually active. On further testing, it was found that the discharge has very few lactobacilli and there was a presence of clue cells. What is the most likely causative organism for the above condition _______
questions.solution:
The above case scenario is Bacterial Vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis is termed vaginosis rather than vaginitis because it is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora rather than due to any specific infection.

It is not sexually transmitted and has a variable incubation period. About 50% of women are asymptomatic carriers of infection.

The presence of clue cells is one of the 4 criteria described in Amsel’s criteria.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

On microscopy, there is no abundance of polymorphs in a case of bacterial vaginosis as it is just an alteration of flora and not an inflammation.

  • The diagnosis is based on wet smear and culture.
  • The smear reveals clean background with few inflammatory cells and other organ­isms, but scanty lactobacilli. Many epithelial cells present a granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, the so-called clue cells. Gram stain is 90% sensitive.

questions.text: A 40 year old comes to clinic with painless discoloration of the skin. On examination, you see diffuse, patchy areas of hypopigmentation. It is not associated with any other symptoms. The given image illustrates a therapeutic modality of the patient's condition. The mechanism of action of this therapy would include all except _____
questions.solution:
PUVA therapy causes suppression of T lymphocyte action.

  • The UVA spectrum is commonly defined as that between 320 and 400 nm and is usually used in combination with a psoralen photosensitizer, either orally or topically, when it is known as photochemotherapy (PUVA). 
  • The most frequently used psoralens for oral use are 8‐methoxypsoralen (8‐MOP) and 5‐methoxypsoralen (5‐MOP).
  • The mechanisms of action of PUVA
    • Cross‐linking of by psoralen photoadducts
    • Inhibition of DNA replication
    • Langerhans cell depletion
    • Immunosuppressive effects on T‐lymphocyte function
    • Migration and the restoration of Th17/regulatory T-cell imbalance in psoriasis
    • Stimulation of melanogenesis
  • Indications of PUVA therapy
    • Psoriasis
    • Atopic eczema
    • Vitiligo
    • Polymorphic light eruption
    • Cutaneous T cell lymphoma
  • The UVB part of the spectrum is usually defined as that between 280 and 320 nm and just a narrow band of 311-313 nm lamps can be used called as Narrow‐band UV(NBUVB). UVB phototherapy has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive and cytotoxic properties. 
  • Vitiligo may respond both to NB‐UVB and PUVA. NBUVB is more effective than PUVA but response is variable and treatment usually has to be prolonged, often over many months to a year or more.

questions.text: The x ray image shown is that of an individual with history of multiple episodes of painful swelling of the foot. Which of the following is incorrect regarding management of his condition?

choices.text: Allopurinol is the drug of choice for him even if his renal function is compromised
Colchicine can be used for acute attacks
Weight loss causes more severe and frequent attacks

questions.solution:
Weight loss does not cause more severe or frequent attacks.
The image shows Martel’s Sign/ G Sign/ Rat bite erosion which is suggestive of chronic tophaceous gout.
Allopurinol is the drug of choice in chronic tophaceous gout as well as in those with renal insufficiency(with dose adjustment).

Febuxostat is a hypouricemic drug that does not require dose adjustment in renal disease. 

Preventive Measures:

  1. Low Purine Diet
  2. Increased fluid ingestion
  3. Decreased Alcohol intake
  4. Weight loss
  5. Avoiding Diuretics

Treatment of acute attack:

  1. Colchicine
  2. NSAIDs
  3. Glucocorticoids

Treatment of chronic Gout (always started under the cover of NSAIDs)

  1. Uricosuric Drugs (Probenecid or Sulfinpyrazone)
  2. Allopurinol

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hereditary pancreatitis?

choices.text: Most common presentation is chronic pancreatitis

questions.solution:
Hereditary pancreatitis:

  • Hereditary pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with mutations in the cationic trypsinogen gene located on chromosome 7.
  • It has 80% penetrance.
  • The most common presentation of autosomal dominant hereditary pancreatitis is recurrent acute pancreatitis.
  • Patients have a tendency to develop acute pancreatitis while in their teens, progress to chronic pancreatitis in the next two decades, and have a high risk (possibly up to 40%) of developing pancreatic cancer by the age of 70 years.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female presented with pain in neck, fever, malaise and firm enlargement of both lobes of the thyroid after a few days following viral fever. On investigation, thyroid antibodies were normal and serum T4 was slightly raised. The probable diagnosis is __________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of history of viral infection, pain in the neck, and bilateral enlargement of the thyroid lobes suggests a diagnosis of granulomatous thyroiditis (subacute/de Quervain’s thyroiditis).

Granulomatous thyroiditis may follow a viral infection. In a typical subacute presentation, there is pain in the neck, fever, malaise, as well as firm and irregular enlargement of one or both lobes of the thyroid.

There may be raised inflammatory markers, absent thyroid antibodies, serum T4 may be high normal or slightly raised and I123 uptake of the gland is low.

The specific treatment for acute case with severe pain is to give prednisone 10-20 mg daily for 7 days and to gradually taper over the next month. If thyroid failure is prominent, treatment with thyroxine may be required until function recovers.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is most prone to nonunion?
questions.solution:
Among the given fractures, proximal scaphoid fractures are most prone to non-union. 

Since the nutrient artery enters the scaphoid near its distal end, proximal fractures are associated with avascular necrosis and non-union. The more proximal the fracture in the scaphoid, the higher the chances of avascular necrosis and non-union.

Certain bones have a relatively limited or watershed blood supply that can potentially get interrupted by fracture. Fractures in these sites have a higher risk for non-union or the development of osteonecrosis. These sites include:

  • the talar neck
  • the waist of the scaphoid
  • the proximal metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal, and
  • the femoral neck

Related Pearl: Causes for Non Union

Excessive soft-tissue stripping

Bone loss

Vascular injury

Radiation

Infection

Systemic

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent  Fundus Fluorescent  Angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below, which is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The FFA image shows features suggestive of macular ischemia. The FFA is showing an enlarged fovea avascular zone arrow(white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow) - both of which are suggestive of macular ischemia which when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards diabetic macular ischemia

Interpreting Fluorescein angiography image:

  • Punctate (pinpoint) areas of hyper fluorescence - Microaneurysms
  • Abnormal branching or dilatation of blood vessels - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) or retinal neovascularization
  • Fluorescein leakage - Retinal neovascularization. Leakage in the disc region suggests neovascularization of the disc and leakage in other regions proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • Patchy non-perfused retinal capillaries (seen as filling defects in capillaries) - Ischemia from nonperfused retinal capillaries
  • Increase in the size of the foveal avascular zone - Macular ischemia 

Other Options:

  • Macular oedema would show the characteristic Petaloid appearance
  • Submacular/subretinal haemorrhage would obscure the choroidal dye visualization in the corresponding area, appearing similar to capillary nonperfusion but spreading across vascular zones without a defined pattern. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however, be visualized.
  • Premacular haemorrhage/ Vitreous haemorrhage would obscure the visualization of retinal vasculature even and would appear as a region of hypofluorescence with no retinal vasculature visualization

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI): 1. Hemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitides and, Streptococcus pneumoniae are the most common causative agents 2. Risk is greatest in patients who have undergone splenectomy for trauma 3. Risk is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy 4. Prophylactic vaccination should be done 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy

Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.solution:
The risk of developing OPSI is greatest when splenectomy is done for hematological conditions than for post-trauma. Hence statement (2) is incorrect.

Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitides, Haemophilus influenzae, and Escherichia coli. The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy.

Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery.

In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A poorly controlled diabetic with retinopathy would be placed under?
questions.solution:
ASA GRADE 3: Patient with severe systemic disease (some functional limitations)

  • Poorly controlled diabetes: Severe systemic disease
  • Retinopathy: Functional limitation due to poor vision or loss of vision

- American Society of Anesthesiologists’(ASA) classification is used to define relative risk prior to conscious sedation and surgical anesthesia.

- It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk

American Society of Anesthesiologists’ physical status classification of patients -  Class Definition

  • 1 Normal healthy patient
  • 2 Patient with mild systemic disease (no functional limitations)
  • 3 Patient with severe systemic disease (some functional limitations)
  • 4 Patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life (functionality incapacitated)
  • 5 A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation
  • 6 A brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

 

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists’(ASA) classification is used to define relative risk prior to conscious sedation and surgical anesthesia.

It is simple, reproducible and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA PS Classification & Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
ASA I: A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease Without substantive functional limitations. Eg: current smoker, social alcohol drinker, pregnancy, obesity (30 < BMI < 40), well-controlled DM/HTN, mild lung disease
ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease Substantive functional limitations; One or more moderate to severe diseases. Eg: poorly controlled DM or HTN, COPD, morbid obesity (BMI ≥40), active hepatitis, alcohol dependence or abuse, implanted pacemaker, moderate reduction of ejection fraction, ESRD undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis, premature infant PCA < 60 weeks, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents.
ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Eg: recent ( < 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents, ongoing cardiac ischemia or severe valve dysfunction, severe reduction of ejection fraction, sepsis, DIC, ARD or ESRD not undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis
ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Eg: ruptured abdominal/thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect, ischemic bowel in the face of significant cardiac pathology or multiple organ/system dysfunction
ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

Score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused

Score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to painful stimulus only.

Score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score

One pupil 1

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: Blunting of calyceal fornices on voiding cystourethrogram is first seen in
questions.solution:
Blunting of calyceal fornices on voiding cystourethrogram is seen in  Grade III vesicoureteral reflux.

VUR severity is graded based on the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III: VUR into the dilated ureter and/or minimal blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated ureter and blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression

questions.text: A known patient of parkinsonism, taking levodopa for the past 2 years, presents to you with disorientation, confusion and altered sensorium. What is your next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management should be a reduction in the dose of levodopa.

The patient presents with disorientation, confusion and altered sensorium. This is suggestive of delirium. Antiparkinsonian agents are frequently implicated in causing delirium because of dopamine increase.

Decreasing the dosage of the antiparkinsonian agent has to be weighed against a worsening of motor symptoms.

Clozapine is recommended when:

  • The antiparkinsonian agents cannot be further reduced
  • Delirium persists even after reducing the dose of antiparkinsonian agents

If a patient is not able to tolerate clozapine, alternative antipsychotic agents should be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequently occurring transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) is the most frequently occurring transfusion reaction.

FNHTR :

  • fever and chills
  • starts within 1-6 hours of starting transfusion
  • Mechanism
    • Antibodies directed against donor leukocyte and HLA antigens (sensitization)
    • More common in multiply transfused patients and multiparous women
    • Cytokine accumulation during blood storage
  • Treatment: Stop transfusion, antipyretics
  • Prevention: Leukoreduced products

 

Transfusion reactions

Immune-mediated  Non-immune mediated

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

Allergic reactions

Anaphylactic reaction

Graft versus host disease

Transfusion-related acute lung injury

Fluid overload

Hypothermia

Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia

Iron overload

Transient hypotension

Immunomodulation

Blood-borne infections 

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Anaphylactic reaction

  • Within few seconds-minutes of transfusion
  • Rapid onset of shock, respiratory distress, angioedema
  • Usually occurs in sensitized IgA-deficient recipients who produce anti-IgA antibodies that react with IgA in the transfused blood product.
  • Individuals with severe IgA deficiency should, therefore, receive only IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components.

Allergic/ Urticarial reactions

  • occurs within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Urticaria, flushing, angioedema, pruritis
  • caused by recipient IgE antibodies and mast cell activation

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR)

  • starts within 6 hours of starting a transfusion
  • The most common complication of blood transfusion
  • fever and chills, sometimes with mild dyspnea
  • Mechanism
    • Antibodies directed against donor leukocyte and HLA antigens (sensitization)
    • More common in multiply transfused patients and multiparous women
    • Cytokine accumulation during blood storage
  • Treatment: Stop transfusion, antipyretics
  • Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)

  • occurs within 24 hours of transfusion
  • fever, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, renal failure, and DIC
  • Caused by ABO incompatibility, Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • Pre-existing high-affinity IgM antibodies, rapidly induce complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria.
  • Positive direct Coomb's test, pink plasma
  • Transfusion to be stopped immediately

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR)

  • Occurs after 24 hours (usually 2 weeks) after transfusion
  • Mechanism: This occurs in patients previously sensitized to RBC antigens. They have a negative antibody screen due to low antibody levels. When the patient is transfused with antigen-positive blood, an anamnestic response results in the early production of alloantibody that binds donor RBCs. The transfused, alloantibody-coated RBCs are cleared by the reticuloendothelial system.
  • These are typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis (e.g., low haptoglobin level and elevated lactate dehydrogenase [LDH] level).
  • Clinical features: Mild fever and hemolytic anemia, post-transfusion coomb's test positive (circulating donor RBCs coated with antibody or complement), positive new antibody screen.
  • Treatment: Supportive, additional transfusions may be required

questions.text: The most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease is :
questions.solution:
The most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease is progressive dementia.

Other important CNS manifestations in Whipple's disease are:

  • Personality and mood changes
  • Progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • Focal neurologic presentations
  • Oculomasticatory myorrhythmia - an unusual combination of rhythmic eye and jaw movements which is pathognomonic of Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease associated with CNS symptoms has a poor prognosis.

Note - Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with neuroblastoma.

Whipple's disease:

It is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with central nervous system & cardiac problems.

 

Clinical features:

  • The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by diarrhoea, steatorrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and migratory large-joint arthropathy.
  • Patients may also have ophthalmologic and CNS symptoms.
  • Few patients who develop a relapse after remission may present with dementia.

 

Diagnosis:

  • The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows the presence of PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine, which contain the gram-positive bacilli that are not acid-fast.
  • Some cases may also be diagnosed by T whipplei–specific PCR or immunohistochemistry of duodenal biopsies or extraintestinal fluids or tissues.
  • About 40% of the patients with central nervous. system infections may be asymptomatic. Hence, all suspected patients should routinely undergo an examination of the cerebrospinal fluid by PCR for T whipplei.

 

Treatment: 

  • The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone 1 g intravenously twice daily or meropenem 1 g intravenously three times daily for 2 weeks.
  • It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 12 months.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with fever, ear-ache. On examination, tympanic-membrane appears congested and bulging with loss of landmarks. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Fever, earache, congested and bulging tympanic membrane in a 4-year-old child points towards a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM).

Antibiotics form the mainstay of treatment in acute suppurative otitis media, and once the tympanic membrane is seen bulging, myringotomy should be done. 

Myringotomy is indicated only when there is an impending rupture of tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cardinal feature of the disease pathogenesis primarily involving the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, aka paralysis agitans. Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Note: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is per se not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

questions.text: An intern, on recording BP, noted a 15mm Hg drop in the systolic pressure during the inspiration of the patient. Which of the following conditions will not show this observed phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given phenomenon is the Pulsus paradoxus. It is not seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic pressure by > 10 mmHg with inspiration. It is an exaggeration of the normal response. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Obstructive lung disease
  • Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presented with a belief that his penis is retracting in the abdomen and he will die when it completely retracts, what is this disorder known as?
questions.solution:
Koro is a culture-bound syndrome seen in Asia (including India). The affected male person has the belief that his penis is shrinking and may disappear into his abdominal wall and he may then die. It is usually based on the culturally elaborated fears regarding nocturnal emission and masturbation (particularly in men).

Females are also affected infrequently, with a corresponding belief that their breasts (and/or vulva) are shrinking.

Other culture-bound syndromes:

Dhat syndrome is seen in the Indian subcontinent. It is characterized by the complaint of the passage of dhat (whitish discharge: semen) in urine, multiple somatic symptoms, physical/mental exhaustion, sexual dysfunction. It is based on the belief that semen is precious and loss of semen leads to exhaustion and weakness.

Latah (Startle Reaction) is a syndrome seen in South-East Asia and Japan. Occurring more often in women, latah is typically characterized by the presence of automatic obedience, echolalia, and echopraxia. It is often precipitated by a sudden stimulus, such as loud sound.

questions.text: Which among the following breast cancer subtypes has the least Ki-67 value?
questions.solution:
Luminal A is the most common subtype and has the best prognosis among all subtypes having the least proliferation index- Ki-67.

It has high expression of ER genes and low HER-2 cluster genes.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors(50% to 65% of tumors) –Range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas(“triple-negative” or “basal-like”) are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of abdominal pain and tingling sensation of limbs. She was seen eating paint from the wall of the newly built house. The provisional diagnosis was made and x-ray of both legs was ordered which showed dense lines in the long bones of the child. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of lead poisoning in children is seen due to lead paint and according to the history, it is evident that the case is of lead poisoning and the enzyme defect seen is ALA dehydratase.

Diagnosis:

X-rays will expose dense lines in the long bones of children and red cells undergo a change known as basophilic stippling, where blue-staining remnants of destroyed DNA are seen lining the margins of the red cells.

The main tool for diagnosis is measurement of the blood lead level.

Lead is toxic because it can substitute for calcium in many fundamental cellular processes. Lead can cross red blood cell membranes as well as the blood-brain barrier and enter the neuroglia cells which support brain function.

Heme biosynthesis is initiated by the condensation of succinyl–CoA and glycine in a reaction catalyzed by mitochondrial ALA Synthase.

Condensation of two molecules of ALA, catalyzed by cytosolic ALA dehydratase forms porphobilinogen which is essential in heme synthesis.

Fatal dose: 20g of lead acetate

Fatal period: 1 to 2 days.

Symptoms:

Abdominal pain, headache, anemia, irritability and, in severe cases, seizures, coma and death.

Treatment depends on the blood level and is designed to remove the lead from the body by chelation therapy.

questions.text: A patient complaints of vertigo, double vision and headache. She has fallen multiple times in the past few years and is unable to operate motor vehicles. Her symptoms have been dispersed in time and place with a relapsing pattern.  Ophthalmologic examination is given below. What is the most likely structure affected to cause these symptoms in eye?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and the examination findings point towards a diagnosis of internuclear ophthalmoplegia. The site of lesion in a case of internuclear ophthalmoplegia is medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

The command for left gaze originates from right cerebral cortex and runs to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). An output from the left PPRF runs to the left VI nerve nucleus supplying the left lateral rectus, causing abduction. An output from the left PPRF also goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF causing right eye adduction.

Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who is a known case of  Graves disease  presents to the emergency department with high fever, vomiting and seizures. She has not been taking her thyroid medications for a long time and had fever and cough 2 days back. The cardiac monitor shows arrhythmias. What is the most appropriate management for this patient, in addition to supportive care?
questions.solution:
This patient who has Graves disease and an acute infection, now presents with high fever, vomiting, one seizure and confusion. This is suggestive of thyroid storm or thyrotoxic crises. Management includes supportive measures and large doses of propylthiouracil (500–1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4 h) given orally or via an NG tube and propranolol (60–80 mg PO every 4 h; or 2 mg IV every 4 h). 

Methimazole is used if propylthiouracil is not available. Although identificantion and treatment of the precipitaing factor is important, antibiotics and propranolol alone are not enough - anti-thyroid drugs should be given. 

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration or exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI therapy.

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Central nervous system agitation or depression
  • Cardiovascular and GI dysfunction, including hepatic failure

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion

Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

 Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage the cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was taken up for cesarean section. Spinal anesthesia was given and the patient went into hypotension. The vasopressor of choice would be?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is the vasopressor of choice in pregnant patients developing hypotension following neuraxial anesthesia (spinal and epidural).

Hypotension is more common with spinal anesthesia than epidural anesthesia. Phenylephrine is preferred because besides effectively controlling hypotension, it has less placental transfer and lesser chances of fetal acidosis than ephedrine.

Besides vasopressors, the patient should receive an adequate intravenous fluid bolus of crystalloid like Ringer lactate solution (typically 1000–1500 mL) or colloid (typically 250–500 mL) solution at the time of neural blockade. 

After the administration of the spinal anesthetic injection, the patient is placed supine with left uterine displacement (to prevent aortocaval compression) and supplemental oxygen (40–50%) is given.

Blood pressure should be monitored every 1–2 min until it stabilizes.

Hypotension following epidural anesthesia typically has a slower onset.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with chronic low back pain presented with a urinary tract infection. He was admitted twice in the past 3 months with pneumonia. On examination, he has pallor and bony tenderness.  X-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypercalcemia, High alkaline phosphatase and Normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, High alkaline phosphatase, Elevated ESR
Hypercalcemia, Normal alkaline phosphatase, Normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, Normal alkaline phosphatase, Elevated ESR

questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR is consistent with the suspected diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma as per this case scenario.

The patient has anemia, bony tenderness and lytic bone lesions on skull X-ray. The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma.

The skull demonstrates the typical “punched out” lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma. The lesion represents a purely osteolytic lesion with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal.

* Note: The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple Myeloma is: Vertebral column.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

Metastasis 

Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in vault of skull with bevelled edges)

Lymphoma

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)

Tuberculosis

Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)

Osteomyelitis

Radiation

Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for two months. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The next line of management in a 50-year-old woman with AUB (abnormal uterine bleeding) is an endometrial sampling.

Indications for endometrial sampling:

  • Any female>45 years with AUB
  • A female of age<45 years having exposure to excessive estrogen such as in PCOD, severe obesity, tamoxifen treatment.
  • Woman with failed medical management and persistent bleeding
  • Transvaginal ultrasound findings >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women.

Endometrial sampling may be done by either curettage or aspiration biopsy by pipelle or vibra aspirator.

Note: Transvaginal ultrasound is a better first-line investigation to assess AUB. Since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer. Assessing the reason for AUB and ruling out malignancy in the postmenopausal age group are the initial steps before prescribing any treatment.

This is a FIGO classification, as shown below:

Anatomical causes 

Non structural causes

P: Polyp

A: Adenomyosis

L: Leiomyoma

M: Malignancy & Hyperplasia 

C: Coagulopathy

O: Ovulatory dysfunction

E: Endometrial

I: Iatrogenic

N: Not yet classified

questions.text: Which of the following findings is the earliest and most specific for the diagnosis of acute pericarditis?

choices.text: Echocardiography showing echo-free space between the layers of pericardium
ECG showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression
ECG showing ST-segment depression with tall T waves

questions.solution:
EcG showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression is the most sensitive, and specific diagnostic finding, respectively for acute pericarditis.

The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolves through four stages:

  • Stage 1- Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

Echocardiography may be normal or may reveal pericardial effusion. If abnormal, regular echocardiographic monitoring is recommended.

The ECG below shows acute pericarditis causing diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V2 to V6, with reciprocal ST depressions in lead aVR.

questions.text: A procedure designed to induce feared physiological sensations, but under a controlled circumstance is called?
questions.solution:
Interoceptive exposure is a procedure designed to induce feared physiological sensations under controlled circumstances.

Interoceptive exposure is a form of exposure therapy for the treatment for panic disorder and specific phobias. It is done using an activity that produces similar physiological sensations to the ones that are produced during the panic attack.The purpose is to promote habituation of fear in response to them.

Example: Aerobic exercise to induce rapid heart rate and shortness of breath, Breathing through thin straw produces sensation of not getting enough air.

Other options:

Option B: Imaginal exposure typically involves having the patient close their eyes and imagine feared stimuli.

Option C: In vivo exposure involves helping patients directly confront feared objects, activities, and situations.

Option D: Flooding approach involves repeated and prolonged exposure to fear cues of high intensity without relaxation.

questions.text: After a surgery, the surgeon asked the intern to remove the Foley's catheter but he/she could not do it. The surgeon himself tried to remove it but he was unsuccessful as well. What should be the next step of action?

choices.text: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to overdistend the balloon until it bursts and Foley's can be removed
Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon after inflating with 20ml water

questions.solution:
The best technique in this situation is ultrasound-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water. It is important subsequently to cystoscope the patient to ensure that any fragments are removed before they can form a foreign body calculus.

A retained Foley catheter is usually caused by blockage of the channel that connects the balloon to the side arm. Cutting off the side arm and attempting to clear the channel with a wire is only occasionally successful.

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to?
questions.solution:
Raised ESR in pregnancy is due to an increase in fibrinogen and globulin levels.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. The fibrinogen level is raised by 50% during pregnancy. As a result of rise in fibrinogen and globulin level and diminished blood viscosity, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) gives a much higher value (fourfold increase) during pregnancy.

Total plasma protein increases during pregnancy. However, due to hemodilution, plasma protein concentration falls. This results in diminished viscosity of the blood and reduced colloid osmotic tension. Because of marked fall in albumin level and only slight rise of globulin (mainly alpha-globulin), the normal albumin: globulin ratio of 1.7:1 is diminished to 1:1.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought with complaints of bedwetting at night. There is no history of bedwetting during day time. His urine examination was normal. Specific gravity was 1.020. What would be your advice?
questions.solution:
According to the given history, the child had nocturnal enuresis with normal findings on urine examination and hence consulting a child psychologist is the most appropriate option.

Nocturnal enuresis:

  • It refers to the occurrence of involuntary voiding at night after 5 years of age.
  • If no daytime symptoms and physical and urine examination are normal, then further evaluation for urinary tract pathology is not warranted.
  • An USG is done in an older child (usually >7 years) with enuresis or in those who do not respond to therapy.
  • Active treatment should be avoided in children younger than 6 years of age.
  • Psychological therapy includes motivational therapy (star charts), Conditioning therapy (auditory or vibratory alarms) and self-hypnosis. It helps the child to deal with enuresis psychologically and motivate the child to void at night if he wakes up with a full bladder.
  • Pharmacological therapy ( imipramine and desmopressin) is intended to treat the symptoms of enuresis and thus is regarded as second line and is not curative. Desmopressin tablet with a dosage of 0.2-0.6 mg at bed time can be given.

questions.text: Tinea unguium is dermatophyte infection of  the _________
questions.solution:
Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus.

  • Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many fungi may be causative.
  • Clinical features : A yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.
  • Six distinct patterns of tinea unguium have been described.
    • Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) - Most common form
    • Superficial onychomycosis (SO)
    • Proximal subungual onychomycosis
    • Endonyx onychomycosis
    • Totally dystrophic onychomycosis
    • Mixed onychomycosis
  • Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curettings that include dystrophic subungual debris.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with vomiting for 5 days. His sister, who has coeliac disease had similar symptoms. IgA-tissue transglutaminase titre is 5 times the upper limit of normal. Which of the following is not an extraintestinal manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The boy is suffering from coeliac disease. Polycythemia is not an extraintestinal manifestation of coeliac disease.

On the contrary, the most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease in the paediatric age group is iron-deficiency anaemia that is refractory to iron therapy, and not polycythemia.

Celiac disease is an immune-mediated systemic disorder triggered by the ingestion of wheat gluten and related prolamines from rye and barley.

The intestinal symptoms are caused by the atrophy of the small bowel mucosa and malabsorption. The symptoms include diarrhoea, vomiting, anorexia, weight loss, failure to thrive, rectal prolapse, and intussusception.

The extraintestinal manifestations are caused due to malnutrition and autoimmunity and they include the following:

questions.text: What is the most common fetal complication of placenta praevia?
questions.solution:
The most common fetal complication of placenta praevia is low birth weight. Whereas, most common fetal complication of abruptio placentae is prematurity.

  • Low birth weight: 15% (Most common fetal complication)
  • Birth Asphyxia
  • IUD
  • Birth injuries
  • Congenital malformations (3x risk)

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the OG clinic with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her UPT is positive. There is a family history of a thalassemic child in a 1st-degree relative is present. Which of the following is not true about chorionic villous sampling _________

choices.text: Gives results pretty early in a pregnancy
Suitable for the detection of chromosomal abnormalities
Suitable for the detection of inborn errors of metabolism
Suitable for the detection of neural tube defects

questions.solution:
Chorionic villous sampling is not suitable for the detection of neural tube defects.

Chorionic villous sampling:

Study material

Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells

Time

10-13 weeks (transcervically)

10 weeks-term (transabdominally)

Indications

To detect chromosomal abnormalities such as down syndrome.

To detect inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria.

For DNA analysis as in hemoglobinopathies, thalassemia, and sickle cell anemia.
Complications

Abortion (CVS> Amniocentesis)

Limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular defects (when done before 10 weeks)

It is not suitable for the detection of neural tube defects. Amniocentesis is done to detect neural tube defects.

questions.text: A barber aged 42 years presented with lipodermatosclerosis over lower medial aspect of right leg, along with healed venous ulcer. As per the CEAP (Clinical, Etiology, Anatomical, Pathological) classification, his clinical classification will be?
questions.solution:
According to CEAP classification, healed venous ulcer with lipodermatosclerosis comes under the clinical class of C5.
