questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG classically depicts polymorphic ventricular tachycardia—torsades de pointes. Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance.

There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

The other cause of torsades de pointes include:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform).
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulphate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate - electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion or intravenous atropine 

Note: Although hypocalcemia is associated with prolongation of QT interval, there are only rare reports of torsades de pointes associated with hypocalcemia. So, among the above options, the best answer would be hypokalemia.

questions.text: An infant was delivered at 39 weeks of gestation through emergency c-section due to fetal distress. Following delivery, the infant was cyanotic and apneic. What is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Room air is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation in term infants.

Resuscitation with room air in term infants is as effective as using 100% oxygen. By using room air, we may reduce the risk of hyperoxia which is associated with decreased cerebral blood flow and generation of oxygen free radicals.

If the neonate does not achieve normal oxygen saturation levels within 90 seconds, increasing concentrations of oxygen should be blended in (up to 100% oxygen) until normal oxygen saturation levels are achieved.

If pulmonary hypertension is suspected (meconium aspiration, diaphragmatic hernia), one may consider 100% oxygen as the initial gas for resuscitation. Resuscitation of most preterm infants can be initiated with a slightly higher fraction of inspired oxygen (21–30%).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following findings may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Cyanosis is not seen when deoxygenated haemoglobin is 2 gm/dL, it becomes apparent when the concentration of deoxygenated/reduced haemoglobin exceeds 5 gm/dL.

Cyanosis is the bluish discolouration of the skin and mucous membranes. Cyanosis is caused by deoxygenated haemoglobin and abnormal haemoglobin. Oxygen might not reach haemoglobin in an adequate or sufficient amount.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥ 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥ 0.5 gm%.

Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation falls to 85%. In dark-skinned people, it may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.text: Physiological calcification is seen in all of the structures except _____________.
questions.solution:
Physiologic calcification is not seen in the red nucleus.

Image: Calcification in the pineal gland

Image: Heavily calcified falx

Related Pearl: Sites of normal intracranial calcification

  • Pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure
  • Choroid plexus
  • The dura
  • Ligaments (petroclinoid and interclinoid)
  • Pacchionian bodies
  • Basal ganglia - physiological only in a senile person
  • Pituitary gland
  • Arachnoid granulations

NOTE: The lens (not intracranial) can also be seen as a calcified structure

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding salivary gland neoplasms are correct?
1.	80-90% of parotid gland tumors are malignant
2.	90% of sublingual tumors are malignant
3.	60-70% of submandibular gland tumors are benign
4.	Parotid gland is the most common site for salivary gland tumors
questions.solution:
Parotid gland is the most common site for salivary gland tumors and most of them are benign (80-90%). In contrast, 90% of the sublingual gland tumors are malignant but rare in occurrence.

Submandibular gland tumors are predominantly benign (60-70%).

questions.text: Regarding SMILE (small incision lenticule extraction), identify the correct statement
questions.solution:
SMILE (small incision lenticule extraction) is a laser refractive surgery.

It is modified form of FLEx (femtosecond lenticule extraction) where instead of raising a flap lenticule is removed through a small incision. It is performed using femtosecond laser.

questions.text: You notice the presence of the following type of lesions over the arms and around the chin in a newborn baby at birth. Microscopic examination of theses lesions will reveal:
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over arms in a newborn baby at birth is suggestive of transient Pustular Melanosis. Microscopic examination of these lesions will reveal Neutrophils.

Transient Pustular Melanosis:

  • These are benign lesion seen predominantly in black neonates.
  • They contain neutrophils and is present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles; it lasts for 2-3 days.
  • No therapy is required

Other Normal findings in a newborn:

  • Erythema toxicum: small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Mongolian spots: Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back.
  • Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.
  • Hymenal tags
  • Physiological phimosis

 

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

10. Hymenal tags

11. Physiological phimosis

12. Conjunctival hemorrhage

13. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A person on haloperiodol feels increasingly restless, agitated, and dysphoric and has a severe urge to move for the past 1 week. Which of the following will not be used in his management?
questions.solution:
The person has developed akathisia, which is a side effect of antipsychotic medications. It is treated with propranolol, diphenhydramine (Benadryl), and benztropine. Ropinirole is not used in its treatment.

Ropinirole is used in the treatment of restless leg syndrome, which resembles akathisia without a positive history of antipsychotic medication.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text: Gastrointestinal radiation syndrome typically occurs at exposure doses of _________.
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal radiation syndrome occurs after exposure of 600-1000 rad.

  • Acute radiation syndrome is characterized by three main presentations: hematopoietic, gastrointestinal, and neurological/vascular.
  • Hematopoietic: This syndrome is marked by aplastic anemia. This occurs at 2–3 Gy or higher. This may result in infections, bleeding, anemia due to few red blood cells in the circulation.
  • Gastrointestinal: This syndrome often follows absorbed doses of 6-7 Gy (600–1000 rad). The signs and symptoms include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and abdominal pain.
  • Neurovascular: This syndrome typically occurs at absorbed doses greater than 30 Gy (3000 rad), though it may occur at 10 Gy (1000 rad). It presents with neurological symptoms such as dizziness, headache, or decreased level of consciousness, occurring within minutes to a few hours, and with an absence of vomiting. It is invariably fatal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the treatment of the condition depicted below?

choices.text: Physiotheraphy is successful when the restriction of motion is less than 30 degrees
The most common surgical method is subcutaneous tenotomy
Tenotomy is delayed until fibromatosis has evolved completely
Surgery  done after 5 years of age corrects the secondary deformities better

questions.solution:
The condition depicted above is congenital torticollis (wryneck) and the secondary deformities are less corrected if surgery is done after 5 years of age.

Congenital muscle torticollis (CMT) is a condition associated with fibromatosis in the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The mass is usually present by birth, attains its maximum size in one or two months, and disappears by one year of age.

Exercise therapy:

Only conservative treatment is indicated in infancy. The parents are instructed to rotate the child's chin towards the shoulder on the affected side and tilt the head to the opposite side.

Criteria for physiotherapy:

  • Restriction of motion is to be less than 30 degrees
  • No facial asymmetry is to be present.

Surgical therapy:

If the mass does not resolve within one year, it may become permanently fibrotic and contracted leading to torticollis, and a surgical intervention may be required. Ideally, the surgery is performed just before school age.

  • Subcutaneous tenotomy is the most commonly done surgery. It is done in younger children. The technique involves tenotomy of the distal part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

  • Open tenotomy is asurgical method where an additional incision of the deep cervical fascial layer is done.
Age at which open tenotomy is performed Probable effects
Before 1 year Tethering of scar to deeper tissues
1 - 4 years Less satisfactory correction of the tilt of head and facial asymmetry 
After 5 years Secondary deformites are less corrected

The open tenotomy is of two types: Unipolar release and Bipolar release, depending on whether the sternocleidomastoid is release from one or both of its attachments.

Unipolar release may lead to tethering of the scar to deeper tissues, usually in young children. Therefore it is done in children older than 4 years of age.

Frekel's modified bipolar release and Z-plasty of the muscle is done in children with severe deformity or after a failed operation.

questions.text: What is the GCS score of an RTA victim who opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, makes some incomprehensible sounds, and has the following posture?
questions.solution:
The GCS score based on the given clinical scenario is 7.

It is calculated as follows

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • Decorticate posturing/abnormal flexion  - 3 

In the decorticate posture, elbows, wrists, and fingers are flexed, and the legs extended and rotated inward, as seen in the image.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

Motor Response Score

Withdrawal/flexion 4

Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a history of severe abdominal pain for the past 1 day and 3 episodes of vomiting. There is no history of constipation. Blood investigations showed elevated serum amylase levels and ultrasonography showed the presence of acute pancreatitis. All of the following derangements can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is not a complication of acute pancreatitis.

Hypocalcemia is a complication of acute pancreatitis. The mechanism of hypocalcemia during the early stage of acute pancreatitis (within 1st week) differs from the mechanism during the late stages of pancreatitis.

The pancreatic enzymes cause autodigestion of the mesenteric fat leading to the release of free fatty acids. These free fatty acids combine with calcium to form calcium salts, causing low levels of circulating calcium.

Note:

Hypercalcemia may cause acute pancreatitis. Hypocalcemia is a complication of acute pancreatitis. 

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding Haab’s Striae?

1. Not seen in juvenile glaucoma

2. Usually Horizontal or concentric to the limbus

3. Are usually indistinguishable from birth trauma striae

4. Persist even after control of glaucoma
questions.solution:
Haab striae are tears in the Descemet’s membrane of the cornea that are seen as double ‘tram-track’ lines concentric to the limbus.

They are seen in Congenital glaucoma (Buphthalmos), not juvenile glaucoma.

They can be easily distinguished from traumatic striae that are usually not concentric to the limbus. Vertical or oblique lines representing tears in the Descemet’s membrane are seen in birth trauma.

Haab’s striae usually persist even after the control of glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)

Several genes have been implicated, prominently CYP1B1.

 

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures
